texts.shortText: Strange, semi-transparent, blind, eel-like organisms that represent a link between invertebrates and true vertebrates. Body pointed at both ends and with a short fin extending all the way along the back and around the tail. There is a well-developed notochord (primitive backbone), an anterior mouth encircled by short cirri, a series of gill slits and the body is divided into obviously visible muscle blocks.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to about Algoa Bay.

Of evolutionary interest, as represent a link between the invertebrates and vertebrates, as have well-developed gill-slits and notocord (primitive backbone), but lack a true head, brain or skull and the gill slits are used primarily for feeding, rather than for respiration. Also lack red blood cells and haemoglobin typical of vertebrates.

When alive lancelets are very active and swim a short distance before quickly burrowing into the sediment when disturbed. When settled they sit with the body buried and just head projecting upwards into the water column.  Not found intertidally, but common in benthic sediments, especially in False Bay.
Filter water into the mouth and capture fine food particles on a mucous sheet is continually produced and flows over the gill slits before being directed into the digestive tract.
Sexes are separate and spawn synchronously, releasing the eggs and sperm into the water. These develop into larvae which ultimately settle onto the bottom and transform into young lancelets.
Unlikely to be confused with other groups due to the unique body form.
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 244).
